source.7ae3c1d6:
# load in the dataset into a pandas dataframe, print statistics
#df = pd.read_csv('201902-fordgobike-tripdata.csv')
df = pd.read_csv("../input/ford-gobike-2019feb-tripdata/201902-fordgobike-tripdata.csv")

df['start_time'] = pd.to_datetime(df['start_time'])
df['end_time'] = pd.to_datetime(df['end_time'])
# as we found many null data we need to check it 

df = df.dropna()

# drop the columns that not needed for the analysis
df.drop(['start_station_latitude', 'start_station_longitude', 'end_station_latitude', 'end_station_longitude','start_station_id','end_station_id'], inplace = True, axis=1)

df['age']=0
df.age = 2001 - df.member_birth_year
df['age'] = df.apply( lambda row: 2019 - row.member_birth_year , axis=1)

df['duration_min'] = df['duration_sec']/60

age_mean = df.age.mean()

duration_mean=df.duration_min.mean()
figsize=(12, 9)
source.a1ec9396:
fig = plt.figure(figsize = figsize)
ax = plt.subplot(2, 2, 1)

plt.title("Male Trips by Hour of Day");
df.groupby([df[df['member_gender']=='Male']['start_time'].dt.hour]).size().plot(c='b')

plt.axvline(8, linestyle = '--', color='r')
plt.xticks([_ for _ in range(0,24,2)])
plt.axvline(17,linestyle = '--', color='r');

ax = plt.subplot(2, 2, 2)
plt.title("Female Trips by Hour of Day");
df.groupby([df[df['member_gender']=='Female']['start_time'].dt.hour]).size().plot(c='DeepPink')
plt.axvline(8, linestyle = '--', color='r')
plt.xticks([_ for _ in range(0,24,2)])
plt.axvline(17,linestyle = '--', color='r');

ax = plt.subplot(2, 2, 3)
df.groupby([df[df['member_gender']=='Male']['end_time'].dt.hour]).size().plot(c='b')
plt.axvline(8, linestyle = '--', color='r')
plt.xticks([_ for _ in range(0,24,2)])
plt.axvline(17,linestyle = '--', color='r');

ax = plt.subplot(2, 2, 4)
df.groupby([df[df['member_gender']=='Female']['end_time'].dt.hour]).size().plot(c='DeepPink')
plt.axvline(8, linestyle = '--', color='r')
plt.xticks([_ for _ in range(0,24,2)])
plt.axvline(17,linestyle = '--', color='r');
plt.show()

print("""* Most of the trips start at 8AM and at 5PM.
* Males prefer to use the bikes in 5pm more than 8am.
* Females prefer to use bikes in the morning than afternoon.""")

source.edd54476:
## Investigation Overview

In this investigation, I wanted to look at the user's characteristics of GoBike along the period of 2/2019 that could be used to predict their long run usage and that will help for providing better sevice

## Dataset Overview

This document explores a dataset containing bike trips of 2/2019 for approximately 174,000 record. with 11 feature , in this analysis I am interested about ( age, gender , user type , duration of usage, time of usage) these will provide us us with the suffesiont data and predection

source.86b47209:
### What is the structure of your dataset? There are 183412 trip in the dataset with 16 features (duration_sec, start_time, end_time, start_station_id, start_station_name, start_station_latitude, start_station_longitude, end_station_id, end_station_name, end_station_latitude, end_station_longitude, bike_id, user_type, member_birth_year, member_gender and bike_share_for_all_trip). Most variables are numeric in nature, but the variables start_station_name, end_station_name, user_type ,member_gender and bike_share_for_all_trip are ordered factor variables with the following levels. user_type: 'Customer', 'Subscriber'
bike_share_for_all_trip: 'No', 'Yes'
member_gender: 'Male', 'Other', 'Female' ### What is/are the main feature(s) of interest in your dataset? I'm most interested in figuring out what features are best for analysing the the most used trip and the customer behaviour in the dataset. ### What features in the dataset do you think will help support your investigation into your feature(s) of interest? I expect that start_station_name and end_station_name will have the strongest effect on most used trip: most repeated stations , the higher the used. I also think that the analysis of type and gender will give clear picture of the bike using.
